THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Natural Resources, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Andy McDonald, Jason Martin and Jonathan Corn, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Abbeville County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4081
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 13, 2006Â Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        James Wofford Bannister, of Greenville, for Appellants.
        James Andrew Quinn, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Andy McDonald, Jason Martin, and Jonathan Corn (Defendants) were convicted in magistrateâ€™s court of hunting deer over bait in Abbeville County.Â  The circuit court affirmed the convictions, rejecting Defendantsâ€™ argument that the regulation they allegedly violated was ineffective on the date in question because the statute on which it was based had been repealed.Â  Defendants appeal to this court.Â  We reverse.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On May 26, 1995, Regulation 2.9 was published in Volume 19, Issue 5 of the South Carolina State Register.Â  The South Carolina Wildlife and Marine Resources Department (now the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources) enacted Regulation 2.9 as part of 27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 123-40 (1982).Â  Specifically, Regulation 2.9 prohibits (1) â€œbaiting or hunting over a baited area or taking wildlife over a baited areaâ€ on all wildlife management area lands[2]; and (2) baiting, hunting over bait, or taking over bait â€œBig Gameâ€ on â€œother lands within the Central Piedmont, Western Piedmont and Mountain Hunt Units.â€[3]Â  
When the Department promulgated Regulation 2.9, it incorrectly cited only South Carolina Code section 50-9-150 as the enabling statutory authority.Â  Section 50-9-150 granted the Department authority to prescribe methods for taking game; however, this authority was limited to activity on wildlife management areas.[4]Â  Although South Carolina Code section 50-11-310 authorized the Department to regulate deer hunting on land other than wildlife management areas,[5] the Department did not cite this section when it promulgated Regulation 2.9.Â  
The time limit to challenge the procedural validity of Regulation 2.9 expired without incident on May 26, 1996.[6]Â  On May 30, 1996, the South Carolina General Assembly passed Act 372, which amended Chapter 9 of Title 50 of the South Carolina Code.[7]Â  Although section 50-9-150 was not listed among the statutes expressly repealed by Act 372, the legislature significantly revised many of its provisions and incorporated them elsewhere within Title 50.[8]Â  Act 372 took effect July 1, 1996.[9]Â  
On November 10, 2001, Eddie Monts, an officer with the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources observed Defendants hunting deer over bait in Abbeville County.Â  Monts arrested Defendants and charged them under South Carolina Code section 50-11-350 for violating Regulation 2.9.[10]Â  From the briefs and record on appeal, it appears Defendants were not hunting in a wildlife management area when Monts apprehended them.
After denying a motion by Defendants to dismiss the charges for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, the magistrate conducted a trial and convicted Defendants as charged.Â  Defendants appealed to the Court of Common Pleas for Abbeville County, which heard the matter on March 4, 2004.Â  On April 15, 2004, the circuit court issued an opinion affirming the convictions.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The dispositive issue in this appeal is whether the repeal of a statute given as the authority for the promulgation of an administrative regulation bars a prosecution for a violation of that regulation.Â  We hold it does, notwithstanding the presence of other statutory authority that arguably could have supported the regulation but was not cited when the agency promulgated the regulation.
â€œAn administrative agency has only such powers as have been conferred by law and must act within the authority granted for that purpose.â€[11]Â  With regard to rulemaking, the South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act requires an agency to give notice of the proposed action in the State Register[12] and to include in the notice â€œthe agencyâ€™s statutory authority for promulgating the regulation.â€[13]Â  
â€œThe general rule is that the repeal of a statute operates retrospectively, and has the effect of blotting it out as completely as if it had never existed and of putting an end to all proceedings under it.â€[14]Â  Although an administrative agency may have the power to enforce a repealed statute, this authority exists only if there is an applicable savings clause and the violation at issue precedes the expiration date of the statute.[15]
The circuit court characterized the Departmentâ€™s failure to list the correct statutory authority for Regulation 2.9 as â€œmerely a procedural errorâ€ and held that, under South Carolina Code section 1-23-110(D), a challenge had to have been made by May 26, 1996, one year after the effective date of the regulation.[16]Â  The court concluded that â€œthe statute of limitations has run on [Regulation 2.9]â€ and that â€œ[b]ecause statutory authority for the regulation continued to exist after the repeal of S.C. Code Â§ 50-9-150, the regulation remained in force.â€
We find the circuit courtâ€™s analysis troubling for a number of reasons.Â  
Initially, we had some concern as to whether section 50-9-150 had in fact been repealed.Â  Although the 2005 supplement to Title 50 of the South Carolina Code indicates section 50-9-150 had been â€œRepealed by 1996 Act No. 372, Â§ 2, eff. July 1, 1996,â€ it was not among those statutes expressly repealed by this legislation, all of which were listed in section 5 of Act 372.Â  In addition, the general presumption against the legislative intention to repeal a statute when express terms of repeal are not used[17] and the fact that the General Assembly has not yet adopted the 2004 supplement[18] have prompted us to review the history of section 50-9-150 for the limited purpose of determining whether, in the present appeal, it can support Defendantsâ€™ convictions.
Notwithstanding our initial concern, we hold that, for the purpose of deciding this appeal, it was correct to rely on the premise that section 50-9-150 had been repealed, at least to the extent that this statute cannot support the convictions at issue.Â  The preamble to section 2 of Act 372, entitled â€œHunting, fishing, and trapping licenses revised,â€ states that the purpose of the section is to â€œfurther amend[ ]â€ Chapter 9, Title 50 of the South Carolina Code to read in a particular way, rather than to simply add or delete certain provisions.[19]Â  Moreover, after examining the specific provisions of the version of section 50-9-150 in effect during the promulgation of Regulation 2.9,[20] we are of the opinion that the only one that has remained intact after the passage of Act 372 was the delegation of authority to the Department to â€œestablish open and closed seasons, bag limits, and methods for hunting and taking wildlife on all wildlife management areas.â€[21]Â  As the Department appears to have conceded, however, this provision cannot support Regulation 2.9 insofar as that regulation governs hunting on lands that are not within wildlife management areas.[22]
Turning to the arguments Defendants have raised on appeal, we first question the significance the circuit court ascribed to the fact that Regulation 2.9 went unchallenged for one year after its publication in the State Register.Â  This controversy does not concern procedural noncompliance in promulgating a regulation; rather, the question is whether the repeal of section 50-9-150, the statute referenced during the promulgation of Regulation 2.9, operates as a repeal of the regulation itself.Â  We hold that it does.[23]Â  
In so holding, we cite with favor In re Terrence M.,[24] on which Defendants rely in their appeals to both the circuit court and to this court.Â  In that case, this court sua sponte vacated an adjudication of delinquency based on the repeal of the statute under which the juvenile was charged.[25]Â  
The circuit court attempted to distinguish Terrence M. from the present controversy, relying on the argument that â€œDefendants violated a regulation that was backed by several points of statutory authority,â€ reasoning that â€œ[i]f separate statutory authority had existed in [Terrence M.], it would have been affirmed.â€Â  
Irrespective of whether the delinquency adjudication in Terrence M. would have remained valid had there been other statutory authority that could have supported it, we are of the opinion that no court in this State has the authority to uphold a regulation by gratuitously considering statutory authority that the enacting agency apparently failed to consider during the rulemaking process.Â  We base this holding on Global Van Lines, Inc. v. Interstate Commerce Commission,[26] a case Defendants cited in their brief to this court.Â  
In Global Van Lines, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, in construing a provision of the Federal Administrative Procedures Act analogous to section 1-23-110(A)(1)(c), noted that Congress, when enacting the Act, stated that â€œâ€˜[a]gency notice must be sufficient to fairly apprise interested parties of the issues involved, so that they may present responsive data or argument relating theretoâ€™â€[27] and that â€œâ€˜[t]he required specification of legal authority must be done with particularity.â€™â€[28]Â  The court refused to determine whether the regulation at issue in the case could be upheld on the basis of a statute that had not been mentioned in the notice of proposed rulemaking, explaining as follows:

  [The Federal Administrative Procedures Act] . . . at the very least requires that the legal grounds upon which the agency thought it was proceeding appear somewhere in the administrative record.Â  A decision of that magnitude should not be left to the imagination of counsel on appeal, for â€œ[t]he purpose of requiring a statement of the basis and purpose is to enable courts, which have the duty to exercise review, to be aware of the legal and factual framework underlying the agencyâ€™s action.â€ . . . It has, moreover, been settled for at least forty years that â€œ[t]he grounds upon which an administrative order must be judged are those upon which the record discloses that its action was based.â€Â  Speculations about what might have been good reasons had the agency only thought of them do not suffice.[29]

Likewise, we agree with Defendants that their convictions cannot be upheld on the basis of a statute that was never cited in the promulgation of the regulation that they were charged with violating.Â  
CONCLUSION
The prohibition in Regulation 2.9 against hunting over bait on locations outside wildlife management areas is no longer enforceable.Â  The statute cited as the enabling legislation for the regulation is no longer in effect as enacted, and the only intact provision of the statute authorizes the Department of Natural Resources to regulate hunting only on wildlife management area lands.Â  Because the violations at issue here concerned a defunct prohibition, Defendantsâ€™ convictions were improper.[30]
REVERSED.
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

Jur. 2d Statutes Â§ 291, at 459 (2001) (â€œIf the later act is intended to cover the entire subject and to be a substitute for the earlier act, the omitted parts are deemed to be repealed by implication.Â  This is true of an amendment which declares that the earlier statute will read in a particular way.â€) (emphasis added).

title: State v. Elmore
description: This criminal appeal presents the issues of whether the trial court erred in refusing to grant a motion for a directed verdict and in ruling that the State could use two prior drug convictions for impeachment if the defendant testified.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
David Bernard Elmore, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Saluda County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4082Â Â 
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 21, 2006 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
C. Rauch Wise and Robert J. Tinsley, both of Greenwood, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Special Assistant Attorney General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  David Bernard Elmore appeals his conviction and sentence for possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  Elmore argues the trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for a directed verdict and erred in ruling the State could use two prior drug convictions for impeachment if he testified.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
On December 16, 2001, Deputies Mike Rushton and Chuck Padgett of the Saluda County Sheriffâ€™s Office were on patrol on Highway 178 in Saluda County.Â  The deputies observed a white Cadillac cross the center line.Â  The deputies suspected the driver of the Cadillac was driving under the influence and pulled the car over.Â  
After the car was pulled over, the deputies noticed several bags fly out of the vehicleâ€™s passenger side window.Â  Deputy Rushton approached the car and asked the driver (and sole occupant), David Bernard Elmore, for his driverâ€™s license.Â  Elmore did not have a license and was arrested for driving without a license.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â  
The deputies searched Elmore, the car, and the ground around the car.Â  Eight small plastic sandwich bags, each containing a green leafy substance, were found on the side of the road; one larger bag, containing a similar substance, was found in the Cadillacâ€™s center console.Â  Elmore was carrying $653 in cash in his pockets.Â  The deputies found no marijuana residue, no evidence of marijuana being smoked in the car, and no drug paraphernaliaâ€”â€œno cigarette lighters, no matches, no marijuana smoking pipes or anything of that nature . . . , no rolling papers, [and] no blunts.â€Â  
Testing confirmed the leafy substance was marijuana, and Deputy Rushton testified that the street value of each bag ranged from ten to thirty dollars.Â  The total weight of the marijuana was 27.55 grams.Â  Investigator Joe Collier testified that four of the bags were virtually identical in weight.Â  Elmore was charged with possession with intent to distribute marijuana. 
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, Elmore argued the State failed to prove the element of intent and moved for a directed verdict.Â  The trial court found the State â€œsubmitted evidence that could be viewed by the jury as intent to distributeâ€ and denied the motion.Â  
The trial court then informed Elmore of his right to testify and explained that his prior convictions may be â€œbrought upâ€ if he testified.Â  The Solicitor informed the trial court of the Stateâ€™s desire to question Elmore about two prior drug convictions: a 1995 conviction for possession of crack cocaine; and a 2001 conviction for possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  Elmore contended the convictions were prejudicial and objected to their admission.Â  Specifically, Elmore argued the marijuana conviction should not be allowed because it is â€œunduly similarâ€ and cited Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 527 S.E.2d 98 (2000), and State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 525 S.E.2d 246 (2000).Â  The trial court summarily noted the objection and found the State could ask about both convictions if Elmore testified.Â  Elmore elected not to testify.Â  
Elmore was found guilty of possession with intent to distribute marijuana and sentenced.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS


I.                 
Denial of Motion for a Directed Verdict 
Elmore argues the trial court erred in not granting a directed verdict because there was insufficient evidence to establish an intent to distribute marijuana.Â  We disagree. 
â€œOn appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.â€Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  The trial court, in a directed verdict motion, is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not with its weight.Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 594, 606 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004).Â  This standard remains constant even when the State relies exclusively on circumstantial evidence. Id.Â  â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€Â  McHoney, 344 S.C. at 97, 544 S.E.2d at 36.Â  A trial court should grant a directed verdict motion when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty.Â  State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 409, 535 S.E.2d 126, 127 (2000).Â  However, â€œ[i]f there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€Â  McHoney, 344 S.C. at 97, 544 S.E.2d at 36.Â  
Section 44-53-370(d)(3) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2004) creates a â€œpermissive inference to be considered by the juryâ€ that possession of more than twenty-eight grams or one ounce of marijuana constitutes possession with intent to distribute.[1]Â  State v. Andrews, 324 S.C. 516, 522, 479 S.E.2d 808, 812 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  However, â€œconviction of possession with intent to distribute does not hinge upon the amount involved.â€Â 
State v. Adams, 291 S.C. 132, 134, 352 S.E.2d 483, 485 (1987).Â  â€œPossession of any amount of controlled substance coupled with sufficient indicia of intent to distribute will support a conviction for possession with intent to distribute.â€Â  State v. James, 362 S.C. 557, 561-62, 608 S.E.2d 455, 457 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
Although we find no South Carolina precedent directly on point, we do find instructive two cases with overlapping features.Â  In State v. Robinson, 344 S.C. 220, 224, 543 S.E.2d 249, 250 (Ct. App. 2001), and State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 594-95, 606 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004), sufficient evidence of the intent to distribute was found to withstand motions for directed verdicts.Â  In Robinson, the court found  sufficient indicia of intent to distribute when the State presented testimony from police officers that a user of cocaine would not typically possess seven rocks of cocaine, that a dealer is not typically found with scales or individual baggies in his possession, and that a dealer typically wraps crack cocaine as Robinson did.Â  Robinson, 344 S.C. at 224, 543 S.E.2d at 250.Â  
In State v. Cherry, 348 S.C. 281, 559 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2001) (en banc), affâ€™d in result, 361 S.C. 588, 606 S.E.2d 475 (2004), this court found sufficient evidence of the intent to distribute to withstand a motion for a directed verdict where: (1) the arrest occurred in a high crime area; (2) defendant possessed eight rocks of crack cocaine; (3) defendant possessed no drug paraphernalia; (4) defendant possessed $322 in cash, predominantly in twenty dollar bills; and (5) testimony provided that a single rock of crack cocaine is typically sold for twenty dollars.Â  Cherry, 348 S.C. at 285, 559 S.E.2d at 299.Â  Our supreme court granted a writ of certiorari to review this courtâ€™s opinion in Cherry, and the majority opinion affirmed this issue,[2] holding the above combination of factors was sufficient to submit the charge of possession with intent to distribute to the jury.Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594-95, 606 S.E.2d at 478.Â  The majority further held that, when reviewing a directed verdict motion, the trial court is not required to find the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypothesis.Â  Id. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478.Â Â  
Elmore argues the facts of this case more closely mirror those in State v. James, 362 S.C. 557, 608 S.E.2d 455 (Ct. App. 2004), where this court found evidence was insufficient to submit to the jury a possession with intent to distribute charge.Â  We disagree. 
We believe the facts of the case before us more closely line up with those in Robinson and Cherry.Â  The overlapping features include the number of â€œbaggiesâ€ containing drugs, the method of individual packaging, the amount of cash found on Elmore, and the complete absence of drug paraphernalia.Â  Conversely, James is readily distinguishable.Â  In James, two of the reasons this court found insufficient evidence of intent were: (1) James did not have a large amount of cash on his person, he only possessed thirty-seven dollars; and (2) the amount of crack cocaine possessed by James was speculative, because the bag containing the crack cocaine was never recovered for evidentiary testing and was only seen briefly by the arresting police officer.Â  James, 362 S.C. at 565, 608 S.E.2d at 459.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, as we must, we find the trial court properly denied the directed verdict motion, for a jury question was presented on the element of intent.Â  We construe Elmoreâ€™s final brief as tacitly acknowledging the presence of a jury question.Â  As Elmore puts it: â€œThe fact that marijuana is commonly sold in small packages also means that marijuana is commonly purchased in small packages.Â  With only nine small bags, the evidence is just as susceptible as establishing . . .Â  Elmore had purchased the marijuana in small bags.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  We agree that the evidence is reasonably susceptible of two inferencesâ€”one of which is consistent with the Stateâ€™s theory of possession of marijuana with intent to distribute, especially in view of the commonality of factors shared with Robinson and Cherry.[3]Â  
II.              
Admissibility of Prior Convictions 
Elmore asserts the trial court committed reversible error in ruling the State could impeach him through the use of two prior drug convictions if he testified.Â  We disagree based on supreme court precedent. 
Â â€œ[W]hen the trial judge chooses to make a preliminary ruling on the admissibility of prior convictions to impeach a defendant and the defendant does not testify at trial, the claim of improper impeachment is not preserved for review.â€Â  State v. Glenn, 285 S.C. 384, 385, 330 S.E.2d 285, 286 (1985).Â  In Glenn, the court adopted the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s reasoning in Luce v. United States, 469 U.S. 38 (1984), that â€œwhen the defendant does not testify, appellate review is too speculative for several reasons,â€ including: 

the freedom of the trial judge to later alter his ruling; the possibility the prosecution may not have sought to impeach the defendant with the prior convictions; the likelihood that an adverse ruling might not have been the real motivation for the defendantâ€™s decision not to testify; and the inability of the appellate court to review any error for harmlessness.

Glenn, 285 S.C. at 385, 330 S.E.2d at 285-86.Â  We adhere to the Luce preservation rule adopted in Glenn.Â  See S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 9 (â€œThe decisions of the Supreme Court shall bind the Court of Appeals as precedents.â€).Â  Thus, because Elmore did not testify, we find he failed to preserve the question of improper impeachment for review.Â  
 Elmore urges a departure from a strict application of Glenn, desiring instead a less rigid preservation rule.Â  Some jurisdictions have declined to follow the Luce preservation rule.Â  See generally State v. Galmore, 994 S.W.2d 120, 123-25 (Tenn. 1999) (discussing, for states that have not adopted the Luce preservation rule, the two primary alternative approaches to preserving a challenge to a trial courtâ€™s pre-testimony decision on admissibility of prior convictions for impeachment purposes).Â  As an error correction court, we leave it to our supreme court to determine if a retreat from Glenn is warranted.Â  
We take this opportunity to remind and caution the bench and bar of the inherent prejudice that flows from the use of similar prior convictions for impeachment purposes under Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE. The trial court, in weighing the probative value of prior convictions pursuant to Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE,[4] should consider all relevant factors including but not limited to: â€œ1) the impeachment value of the prior crime; 2) the point in time of the conviction and the witnessâ€™s subsequent history; 3) the similarity between the past crime and the charged crime; 4) the importance of the defendantâ€™s testimony; and 5) the centrality of the credibility issue.â€Â  State v. Bryant, 356 S.C. 485, 490, 589 S.E.2d 775, 777-78 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted) (emphasis added).Â  The current state of the law does not mandate the trial court make an on-the-record specific finding â€œas long as the record reveals that the trial judge did engage in a meaningful balancing of the probative value and the prejudicial effect before admitting a non-609(a)(2) prior conviction under 609(a)(1).â€Â  State v. Scriven, 339 S.C. 333, 341, 529 S.E.2d 71, 75 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  However, as we have urged trial courts, when balancing the probative value of a prior conviction under Rule 609(a)(1) against the prejudicial effect, meaningful appellate review is best achieved when the trial court â€œarticulate[s] its ruling and the basis for it.â€Â  Id. at 342, 529 S.E.2d at 75.Â  
An on-the-record analysis is especially needed when undertaking a balancing that involves a prior similar offense under Rule 609(a)(1).Â  This is because the â€œthe danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant from impeachment by that prior offense weighs against its admission.â€Â  State v. Dunlap, 353 S.C. 539, 542, 579 S.E.2d 318, 320 (2003); see also, Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 434, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 (2000) (finding trial counselâ€™s failure to argue that the prejudicial effect of the convictions outweighed their probative value constituted ineffective assistance of counsel and prejudiced the defendant).Â  Indeed, the similarity of a prior crime to the crime charged heightens the prejudicial value of the crime.Â  State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 628, 525 S.E.2d 246, 249 (2000).Â  Moreover, for prior similar convictions involving violations of narcotics laws, the prejudicial value is further increased as such violations â€œare generally not probative of truthfulness,â€ and â€œthis relative lack of probative value should figure prominently in the weighing of prejudice.â€Â  Dunlap, 353 S.C. at 542, 579 S.E.2d at 320.Â  Thus, we strongly encourage trial courts to engage in an on-the-record analysis when admitting such convictions because of the presumption against their admission.[5] Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court properly denied Elmoreâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  We adhere to the State v. Glenn precedent in holding that Elmoreâ€™s challenge to the trial courtâ€™s presumptive ruling concerning the admissibility of his prior drug convictions for impeachment under Rule 609(a)(1) is not preserved for review.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1]  This section has subsequently been amended and the pertinent language is currently in section 44-53-370(d)(4).Â  See 2005 Act No. 127, Â§ 4 (eff. June 7, 2005).
[2]  The dissent in Cherry took no exception to the majorityâ€™s analysis on the directed verdict issue.Â  361 S.C. at 602-06, 606 S.E.2d 482-04.Â  The dissent advocated reversal based on a challenge to the jury charge on circumstantial evidence.Â  Id.Â  We are not presented with any challenge to the jury charge in the present case.
[3]  In Cherry, the court â€œrejected the contention that in ruling on a directed verdict motion, the trial judge must grant a directed verdict unless the circumstantial evidence pointed conclusively to the defendantâ€™s guilt, to the exclusion of every other reasonable hypothesis.â€Â  Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478, (citing State v. Edwards, 298 S.C. 272, 275, 379 S.E.2d 888, 889, cert. denied, 493 U.S. 895, 110 S. Ct. 246, 107 L. Ed. 2d 196 (1989)).
[4]  We recognize that under a precedent of this court, the use of a prior conviction under Rule 609(a)(2), SCRE, does not require a probative value versus prejudice analysis.Â  State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 425-27, 578 S.E.2d 32, 43-44 (Ct. App. 2003).
[5]  One permissible approach, advocated by the United States Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, is to allow the prosecutor to ask the witness about the existence of a prior similar conviction under Rule 609(a)(1) without disclosing to the jury the nature of the prior offense.Â  See United States v. Boyce, 611 F.2d 530, 531 n.1 (4th Cir. 1979).Â  The Boyce approach was approvingly referenced by our supreme court in Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 433 n.5, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 n.5 (2000).Â  The Boyce approach still requires a meaningful balancing of the probative value and prejudicial effect before admission of the prior conviction, although the prejudice occasioned by the similarity of the prior crime to the crime charged is removed.Â Â

title: Gadson v. Mikasa Corporation
description: n this Workersâ€™ Compensation appeal, appellant posits two issues: (1) the circuit court erred in affirming the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s finding that Gadson had reached maximum medical improvement and was totally and permanently disabled; and (2)  the circuit court erred in adopting the Commissionerâ€™s acceptance of the report of Jean Hutchinson as an expert in vocational evaluation and as a certified rehabilitation counselor, who had filed an APA submission pursuant to Regulation 67-611.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kathleen L. Gadson, Employee, Respondent,
v.
Mikasa Corporation, Employer, The Yasuda Fire & Marine Insurance Co., Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4083
Heard February 6, 2006 â€“ Filed February 21, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Duke K. McCall, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellants.
Thomas M. White, of Goose Creek, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, the employer, Mikasa Corporation, and its insurance carrier, The Yasuda Fire & Marine Insurance Company (collectively referred to as Mikasa) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the appellate panelâ€™s ruling that Kathleen L. Gadson had reached maximum medical improvement and was entitled to permanent disability benefits.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In September of 1997, Kathleen Gadson began working for Mikasa in Charleston, South Carolina.Â  On January 8, 1998, Gadson sustained an injury by accident arising out of and in the course of her employment.Â  She was injured while unloading some boxes.Â  Since January of 1998, Dr. Jeffrey K. Wingate, a spine surgeon with the Carolina Spine Institute, has been her primary treating physician.Â  The single commissioner found Gadson had injuries to her abdomen and lower back.Â  She was awarded temporary total disability and permanent partial disability of ten percent for loss of use and disability to her back.
Subsequently, Gadson filed a Form 50 alleging a material change in her condition and requesting additional benefits.Â  The single commissioner found that Gadson had experienced a material change in her condition entitling her to additional benefits under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-90.Â  Mikasa was required to be responsible for Dr. Wingateâ€™s medical bills and to provide medical care through Dr. Wingate.Â  The appellate panel affirmed the single commissioner.
Following two surgical procedures by Dr. Wingate and the assignment of a permanent impairment rating, Gadson filed a Form 50 alleging that she had reached maximum medical improvement (MMI), was permanently and totally disabled, and was entitled to lifetime medical care.Â  The single commissioner ruled that Gadson was at maximum medical improvement as of May 22, 2002.Â  The commissioner further found that Gadson was permanently and totally disabled under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30.Â  Mikasa appealed asserting that Gadson had not reached MMI and that further medical care and treatment would tend to lessen her period of disability.Â  The appellate panel unanimously affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s order in its entirety.Â  The circuit judge affirmed the appellate panel, concluding there was substantial evidence in the record to support the panelâ€™s findings.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 599 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions, or decisions of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 457, 622 S.E.2d 577, 580 (Ct. App. 2005); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the appellate panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Liberty
Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 611 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 2005); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) (2005).
The substantial evidence rule of the APA governs the standard of review in a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 593 S.E.2d 491 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Lockridge v. Santens of America, Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAny review of the commissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€).Â  Pursuant to the APA, this Courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the appellate panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  See Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 610 S.E.2d 488 (2005); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. # 3, 338 S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005); see also Grant v. Grant Textiles, 361 S.C. 188, 191, 603 S.E.2d 858, 859 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œA reviewing court will not overturn a decision by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission unless the determination is unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an error of law.â€).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004); Jones v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 586 S.E.2d 111 (2003).
The appellate panel is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and is not bound by the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 617 S.E.2d 369 (Ct. App. 2005); Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the appellate panel.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000); Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999); DuRant v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 604 S.E.2d 704 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Where there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the appellate panel are conclusive.Â  Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2002).
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999).Â  It is not within our province to reverse findings of the appellate panel which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Maximum Medical Improvement
Mikasa argues the circuit court erred in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s finding that â€œGadson had reached MMI and that she was totally and permanently disabled.â€Â  Mikasa claims this ruling is not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
Maximum medical improvement is a term used to indicate that a person has reached such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment.Â  Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 622 S.E.2d 577 (Ct. App. 2005); Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 564 S.E.2d 354 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, the fact that a claimant has reached MMI does not preclude a finding the claimant still may require additional medical care or treatment.Â  Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc., 334 S.C. 574, 514 S.E.2d 593 (Ct. App. 1999).
If an employee has reached MMI and remains disabled, then his injury is permanent.Â  Smith v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 335 S.C. 396, 517 S.E.2d 694 (1999).Â  When a claimant receiving temporary benefits reaches MMI and is still disabled, temporary benefits are terminated and the claimant is awarded permanent benefits.Â  Smith, 335 S.C. at 399, 517 S.E.2d at 696; Bass, 366 S.C. at 467, 622 S.E.2d at 585.Â  Once the commission affirms a finding of MMI, it is appropriate to terminate temporary benefits in favor of permanent disability benefits, if warranted by the evidence.Â  Smith, 335 S.C. at 399, 517 S.E.2d at 696.
Dr. Wingate was Gadsonâ€™s authorized treating physician.Â  Gadson was seen by Dr. Wingate on May 7, 2002 â€œas a worsening of condition for her low back pain.â€Â  Prior to that date, she had been last seen on September 14, 2001, when she was having continuing low back and radiating left leg pain.Â  The CT scan from March 25, 2002 showed a solid bony union at L5-S1.Â  In the May 7 note, Dr. Wingate stated that Gadson could consider an L4-5 epidural injection but he doubted she would need any additional surgery.
Gadson returned to Dr. Wingate on May 22, 2002, the date she was determined to be at MMI.Â  Dr. Wingate recommended exercise to manage her symptoms.Â  Dr. Wingate noted he would be happy to see Gadson in the future but declared: â€œIn my opinion she does not need any further surgical intervention or invasive spinal care.â€Â  Gadson was not given a return
appointment.
Defense counsel wrote Dr. Wingate on July 17, 2002, requesting an impairment rating for Gadson.Â  Dr. Wingate responded by letter dated August 15, 2002.Â  He opined:

In my professional opinion, Ms. Gadson has sustained a 30% whole person impairment as a result of the significant injury to her lumbosacral spine, and the ongoing pain, parasthesias and motor weakness that she has to her right lower extremity.Â  I do not feel that she will ever return to gainful employment.Â  She has a sitting and standing intolerance of 15-20 minutes.Â  She also has a severe deconditioning of her spine, and her medical condition in general.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Future medical expenses will most probably include the cost of epidural steroid injections, and intermittent physical therapy. . . . She continues to take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory and muscular relaxant medications, in combination with an antidepressant, which I think is absolutely indicated in clinical terms for her pain syndrome.Â  It is my professional opinion that she will remain on these medications long term at a cost of $200-$250 per month total.
At this point, she has no scheduled follow up visits to return and see me.Â  I have offered her return follow up on a PRN basis if her low back and right thigh pain intensify to the point that she needs further invasive care.Â  For now she will continue with the conservatively oriented medications.Â  Sheâ€™ll return to see me on a PRN basis.Â  Medical follow up will also include annual CBC, SMA-7 laboratory exams to rule out any damage to kidneys or liver as a result of her medical treatments.Â  Sheâ€™s welcome to see me back for further medical follow up as needed.

Gadson returned to Dr. Wingate on January 9, 2003.Â  She had an escalation in her pain â€œsince [the weather] got cold.â€Â  Dr. Wingate noted a â€œchange in [Gadsonâ€™s] overall pain picture.â€Â  Gadson was â€œhaving more intense pain in the low back and down the legs.â€Â  Dr. Wingate recommended a new MRI scan and wanted to see her after the scan.
Gadson saw Dr. Wingate on January 16, 2003.Â  He reviewed the lumbar MRI scan and noted post-surgical changes at L5-S1.Â  He â€œdoubt[ed] that anything immediately would be needed surgically.â€Â  Dr. Wingate recommended that Gadson do her back strengthening and stabilization exercises and continue her medications.Â  He asked Gadson to return in two months.
Gadsonâ€™s last appointment with Dr. Wingate before the hearing was March 19, 2003.Â  Dr. Wingate noted the CT scan showed solid fusion even after the removal of her pedicle screws.Â  He declared: â€œUnfortunately, I have very little to offer [Gadson].Â  There is nothing focal on her exam today.Â  She has no new specific nerve pain or specific muscle weakness in either arm or leg.â€Â  Dr. Wingate suggested Gadson stay on her medication and come back to see him in four to six months.Â  He stated Gadsonâ€™s primary physician should continue to provide her pain medications.
There is substantial evidence in the record that Gadson reached MMI as of May 22, 2002, and was totally and permanently disabled.Â  MMI is a factual determination left to the discretion of the appellate panel.Â  On May 22, 2002, Dr. Wingate released Gadson to be seen on a PRN basis.Â  At that time, Dr. Wingate found Gadson had her hardware removed and she was going to need long term narcotics.Â  He did not schedule her for a return appointment.Â  He noted that she had no scheduled follow-up visits.Â  According to Dr. Wingate, Gadson was not a candidate for any further surgical intervention or invasive spinal care, although it was anticipated that she would be having some ongoing medical care to include injections and possibly physical therapy.Â  The continued treatment was nothing more than maintenance care to maintain Gadsonâ€™s condition.Â  Her last MRI did not reveal that there was any further active medical treatment that could be done.Â  Dr. Wingate gave Gadson an impairment rating. Â He found Gadson would never be able to return to gainful employment and that she had a severe sitting and standing intolerance of fifteen to twenty minutes.Â  In January of 2003, Gadson had temporal escalation in her pain, which was to be expected.Â  Two months later, Dr. Wingate again noted he had nothing further to offer her.Â  Although Dr. Wingate did not specifically say that Gadson reached MMI, it is obvious from his report that he rated her, did not give her a return appointment and noted that she had permanent impairment and disability that would prevent her from being able to work in the future.Â  Nothing in Dr. Wingateâ€™s later notes or records indicates that Gadson was no longer at MMI or that there had been a change in her condition after May 22, 2002.
Mikasa asserts the finding that Gadson reached MMI is unsupported by substantial evidence, primarily because the reports of Dr. Wingate dated January 9, 2003, January 16, 2003, and March 19, 2003 indicate that Gadson â€œneeds further medical treatment so as to lessen her period of disability.â€Â  This assertion has no merit.Â  As in Pearson v. JPS Converter & Indus. Corp., 327 S.C. 393, 397, 489 S.E.2d 219, 221 (Ct. App. 1997), â€œadditional medical treatment may improve [Gadsonâ€™s] overall quality of life and ability to cope, but not otherwise impact the finding on maximum medical improvement.â€
The circuit judge did not err in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Gadson reached MMI as of May 22, 2002, and is totally and permanently disabled.
II.Â  Vocational Evaluation Consultant
Mikasa maintains the circuit court erred â€œin its adoption of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionerâ€™s acceptance of the report of Ms. Jean Hutchinson as an expert under the Administrative Procedures Act without any evidence of her qualifications and/or expertise.â€
At the hearing before the single commissioner, Gadson submitted a vocational evaluation from Hutchinson, who found that Gadson was totally disabled and unable to work in her present condition.Â  Mikasa objected to the report of Hutchinson.Â  Mikasa averred Hutchinson did â€œnot qualify as an expert to render an opinion in the case.â€ The commissioner overruled Mikasaâ€™s objection and admitted the report, noting she would â€œgive it the appropriate weight and certainly in consideration of your objection.â€
A.Â  Regulations 67-611 & 67-612
The utilitarian efficacy of admissibility under Workersâ€™ Compensation regulations is salutary and salubrious.Â  Historically, the regulations allow for written reports and documentation in lieu of live testimony, concomitantly saving time and expense in the presentation of testimony before the single commissioner.
Regulation 67-611 of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission requires that each attorney representing a party file a Form 58, Pre-Hearing Brief, with the commissioner and serve a copy on the opposing party at least ten days prior to the Workersâ€™ Compensation hearing.Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-611(B) (Supp. 2005); Morgan v. JPS Automotives, 321 S.C. 201, 467 S.E.2d 457 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Form 58 requires the filing party to give the names and addresses of the persons known to the parties or counsel to be witnesses.Â  On the Form 58, Gadson typed: â€œ7. Witnesses (designate if expert): Jean Hutchinson â€“ report to be submitted in lieu of live testimony.â€
Pursuant to Regulation 67-612, it is mandated that a moving party provide the report to the opposing party at least fifteen days before the scheduled hearing.Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-612(B)(1) (Supp. 2005).Â  Gadson served defense counsel with his Brief and APA submissions on April 3, 2003, nineteen days before the hearing.Â  Regulation 67-612(D) notes: â€œAny report submitted to the opposing party in accord with (B)(1) [of 67-612] . . . shall be submitted as an APA exhibit at the hearing unless withdrawn with the consent of the other party.â€Â  Included with the Form 58 in the instant case was a listing of all submissions under the APA, including Hutchinsonâ€™s report.Â  The regulations allow for a deposition to be taken should any party request it.Â  Here, there was no such request by
Mikasa.
Regulations authorized by the legislature have the force of law.Â  Gaffney Ledger v. South Carolina Ethics Commâ€™n, 360 S.C. 107, 600 S.E.2d 540 (2004); McNickelâ€™s, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 629, 503 S.E.2d 723 (1998); Goodman v. City of Columbia, 318 S.C. 488, 458 S.E.2d 531 (1995); cf. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-10(4) (2005) (defining â€œRegulationâ€ as â€œeach agency statement of general public applicability that implements or prescribes law or policy or practice requirements of any agency.Â  Policy or guidance issued by an agency other than in a regulation does not have the force or effect of law.â€).Â  However, regulations may not alter or add to the terms of a statute.Â  United States Outdoor Advertising, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 324 S.C. 1, 481 S.E.2d 112 (1997).
Hutchinsonâ€™s report was properly filed as an APA submission and timely served on Mikasa.Â  The regulations allow for APA submissions.Â  Gadson complied with the regulations by giving notice.Â  Further, it was clear from the APA submission and the Brief that the vocational expert would not be testifying live but a report would be submitted in lieu of live testimony.Â  After the service of the Brief on Mikasa, defense counsel made no attempt to depose Hutchinson so as to challenge her credentials or expertise nor did he attempt to subpoena her to the hearing or to subpoena any additional qualifications he may have desired.Â  Mikasa objected to the report at the hearing but made no request to depose Hutchinson at a later date.Â  Moreover, the Administrative Procedures Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-310, et seq., allows for submission of such a report.Â  Thus, Hutchinsonâ€™s report was admissible under the APA and Regulations 67-611 and 67-612.
B.Â  Vocational Expert
Mikasa contends Hutchinsonâ€™s report should have been excluded because â€œthere is no indication that the individual making th[e] report is qualified as an expert or has the expertise to express the opinions set forth in her . . . report.â€Â  We disagree.
The qualification of an expert witness and the admissibility of the expertâ€™s testimony are matters within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 609 S.E.2d 506 (2005); Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 495 S.E.2d 205 (1998).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to admit expert testimony will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 570 S.E.2d 176 (2002); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004).
The test for qualification of an expert is a relative one that is dependent on the particular witnessâ€™s reference to the subject.Â  Wilson v. Rivers, 357 S.C. 447, 593 S.E.2d 603 (2004).Â  Rule 702, SCRE, articulates guidelines for the admissibility of expert testimony.Â  Rule 702 provides: â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€Â  Rule 702, SCRE.Â  There is no abuse of discretion as long as the witness has acquired by study or practical experience such knowledge of the subject matter of his testimony as would enable him to give guidance and assistance to the jury in resolving a factual issue which is beyond the scope of the juryâ€™s good judgment and common knowledge.Â  State v. Henry, 329 S.C. 266, 495 S.E.2d 463 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  For a court to find a witness competent to testify as an expert, the witness must be better qualified than the fact finder to form an opinion on the particular subject of the testimony.Â  Ellis, 358 S.C. at 525, 595 S.E.2d at 825.Â  An expert is not limited to any class of persons acting professionally.Â  Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 487 S.E.2d 596 (1997).Â  There is no exact requirement concerning how knowledge or skill must be acquired.Â  Honea v. Prior, 295 S.C. 526, 369 S.E.2d 846 (Ct. App. 1988).
The party offering the expert has the burden of showing the witness possesses the necessary learning, skill, or practical experience to enable the witness to give opinion testimony.Â  Henry, 329 S.C. at 274, 495 S.E.2d at 466.Â  Generally, however, defects in the amount and quality of the expertâ€™s education or experience go to the weight to be accorded the expertâ€™s testimony and not to its admissibility.Â  Peterson v. National R.R. Passenger Corp., 365 S.C. 391, 618 S.E.2d 903 (2005); Henry, 329 S.C. at 274, 495 S.E.2d at 466; see also Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 580, 560 S.E.2d 624, 629 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAny defect in the education or experience of an expert affects the weight and not the admissibility of the expertâ€™s testimony.â€).
On the cover of the APA submissions, it stated that Hutchinson has a Masters in Education and is submitting a vocational evaluation which was performed on Gadson on October 10, 2002.Â  On page one of Hutchinsonâ€™s report, she noted that she is a â€œVocational Consultant.â€Â  On page seven of her report, Hutchinson indicated she has a Masters in Education, is a â€œCertified Rehabilitation Counselorâ€ and is â€œCertified in Vocational Evaluation.â€
At the hearing before the circuit judge, Gadsonâ€™s attorney explained:

As to the report of Jean Hutchinson, I think the Administrative Procedures Act under 1-23-310 clearly allows us to let it in.Â  Itâ€™s just a question of weight.Â  You donâ€™t need Jean Hutchinsonâ€™s report in this case because the authorized treating physician says sheâ€™ll never return to work, but the report clearly is admissible.Â  The commissioners can give it what weight they want.Â  Jean Hutchinson is someone who has appeared in front of them the last twenty years.Â  Iâ€™ve used her the last twenty-five years.Â  So they know who she is.Â  And her report is--Â Â  (Emphasis added).

The judge responded: â€œSheâ€™s familiar to the Court.â€
Hutchinsonâ€™s qualifications are set forth in her report.Â  She was qualified to give an opinion as to Gadsonâ€™s employability.Â  Any defects in Hutchinsonâ€™s qualifications go to the weight, not the admissibility, of her report.Â  The appellate panel did not err by admitting Hutchinsonâ€™s report.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, we
AFFIRM.
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sabrina McComas, Appellant,
v.
Chris Ross, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
 Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4084
Heard January 9, 2006 â€“ Filed February 21, 2006Â Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Jarrel L. Wigger, of North Charleston, for Appellant.
Margaret M. Urbanic and Michael B. McCall, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 CURETON, A.J.: This is an appeal from the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of McComasâ€™ case for failure to prosecute.Â  We reverse.Â

McComas emphasizes the fact that she had engaged in discovery and had not been dilatory with respect to this case prior to her failure to make a timely appearance.Â  However, Joyner demonstrates a singular instance of nonfeasance may be sufficient ground for dismissal for failure to prosecute.Â  See Joyner, 356 S.C. 460, 589 S.E.2d 762 (affirming the trial courtâ€™s dismissal for failure to prosecute where the appellant failed to seek a writ of mandamus compelling the magistrate court to file a return).
McComas attempts to distinguish the instant case from Small on the basis that here there was no showing of unreasonable neglect.Â  Ross contends that a showing of unreasonable neglect is not necessary for dismissal under Rule 41(b).Â  Further, Ross maintains that even were a showing of unreasonable neglect required, the requisite neglect is inferable by McComasâ€™s failure to showâ€”as was the case in Small.Â  
 Small was decided under former code section 10-1502 of the 1962 Code of Laws.Â  That section expressly provided for dismissal â€œin case of unreasonable neglect on the part of the plaintiff . . . to proceed in the cause against the defendant or defendants served.â€Â  The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure were promulgated in 1985.Â  See McLain v. Ingram, 314 S.C. 359, 360, 444 S.E.2d 512, 512 (1994) (â€œThe adoption of the SCRCP in 1985 heralded a new era in South Carolinaâ€™s civil practice, modernizing and streamlining our system.â€).Â  Rule 41(b), SCRCP, does not specifically require a finding of unreasonable neglect.Â  Don Shevey & Spires, Inc. v. American Motors Realty Corp., 279 S.C. 58, 60, 301 S.E.2d 757, 758 notes that â€œthe trial court may properly dismiss an action for plaintiffâ€™s unreasonable neglect in proceeding with his cause.â€Â  However, Shevey was decided in 1983â€”after the repeal of the 1962 Code, but prior to adoption of the Rules.Â  Joyner v. Glimcher Properties, 356 S.C. 460, 589 S.E.2d 762, which was decided in 2002â€”after promulgation of Rule 41(b)â€”does not mention the unreasonable neglect requirement.Â  
Regardless whether the unreasonable neglect language applies to dismissals for failure to prosecute, I would rule that McComasâ€™s unreasonable neglect is inferable in this case.Â  The Small court professed:

Counsel for plaintiff was apparently in his office and the plaintiff and his witnesses were at their work when the case was called for trial.Â Â  The court notified counsel through the clerk of court that the case had been reached on the trial roster.Â  The only response made by counsel at that time to such notice was to inform the court through the clerk that he could not appear before 2 P.M., several hours later.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the dismissal of the action under the facts.Â  Unreasonable neglect is inferable.

254 S.C. at 443, 175 S.E.2d at 804.
Rule 40(b) lucidly instructs that once placed on the jury trial roster, a case is subject to call.Â  Here, counsel was informed at approximately 11:00 a.m. that the case would be called to trial.Â  McComas failed to present herself over five and one-quarter hours later.Â  She left her house with no means by which her counsel could contact her.Â  Once she learned of her trial, she apparently did not know the location of the courthouse. Â Thus, she neglected (1) to keep open a means of communication with her attorney, and (2) to avail herself of the courthouseâ€™s whereabouts.Â  Under these facts, unreasonable neglect is inferable.Â Â  
Although McComasâ€™s counsel did call several witnesses prior to dismissal, McComas ultimately failed to prosecute her case.Â  There was absolutely no evidence regarding damages presented at trial.Â  Therefore, had McComasâ€™s attorney rested the plaintiffâ€™s case, a verdict would have been directed in favor of Ross for failure to present any evidence on damages.Â  However, McComas did not rest her case.Â  Rather, the trial judge instructed McComas to call her next witness, and the plaintiff could not proceed: she failed to prosecute.Â  Under South Carolina precedent, the trial judge had the discretion to dismiss her case at that time.Â  
The majority opinion essentially declares a court must wait for the plaintiffâ€”the plaintiff need not trouble herself to wait for the court.Â  This decision undermines the utility of Rule 40 and the ability of a circuit judge to effectively administer court.Â  The unfortunate result will be the needless waste of time and state and county resources.Â  I VOTE to AFFIRM.





[1] Monday, September 6, 2004 was Labor Day, and, therefore, a state holiday.Â  
[2] â€œAn order of dismissal for failure to proceed with the suit is in the nature of a discontinuance of the action and is not an adjudication of the merits.â€Â  Small at 443, 175 S.E.2d at 804.Â  Therefore, the supreme court modified the judgment of the trial court â€œso that its effect [was] to dismiss the action without prejudice.â€Â  Id. at 444, 175 S.E.2d at 804.Â  
[3] Small was decided under section 10-1502 of the South Carolina Code (1962), which has since been replaced by Rule 41(b) of the South Carolina Code of Civil Procedure, promulgated in 1985.Â  Though Rule 41(b) does not require the defendant prove unreasonable neglect by the plaintiff to be granted a motion to dismiss for failure to prosecute, we find a reasonableness standard should apply in cases of this kind, as illustrated by the federal cases on point.Â

title: Sloan Construction Company v. SCDOT
description: In this appeal from the grant of a motion to dismiss, the Court analyzes whether South Carolina Code Sections 29-6-250 and 57-5-1660(a)(2) (Supp. 2004) give rise to a private right of action against a violating state agency.
text:
Sloan Constr. Co., Inc. v. Southco Grassing, et al., 13994


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sloan Construction Company, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Southco Grassing, Inc., Wanda Surrett, South Carolina Department of Transportation, and Greer State Bank,
Defendants,
of whom South Carolina Department of Transportation is
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4085
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed February 21, 2006Â Â Â 
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled April 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
T. S. Stern, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
Beacham O. Brooker, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Sloan Construction Company, Inc., (â€œSloanâ€) appeals the dismissal of its action against the South Carolina Department of Transportation (â€œSCDOTâ€), arguing South Carolina Code Sections 29-6-250 and 57-5-1660(a)(2) (Supp. 2004) give rise to a private right of action against a violating state agency.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The facts of this case are largely uncontested.Â  SCDOT hired Southco Grassing, Inc., (â€œSouthcoâ€) as the general contractor on state highway project no. 23.504 (â€œthe Projectâ€).Â  Pursuant to South Carolina Code Sections 29-6-250 and 57-5-1660(a)(2) (Supp. 2004), Southco provided SCDOT with proof it acquired a payment bond valued at 100% of the $440,016.90 contract amount.Â  Amwest Surety Insurance Company (â€œAmwest Suretyâ€), a company qualified and licensed for surety authority by the South Carolina Department of Insurance with an A- rating from the A.M. Best Company, issued the bond.
In November 2000, Sloan entered into a subcontractor agreement with Southco in connection with the Project.Â  Over the course of Sloanâ€™s contract performance, Amwest Surety was judged insolvent by the insurance commissioner of Nebraska, the companyâ€™s home state.Â  In June 2001, the Nebraska courts ordered Amwest Surety to liquidate all its assets.Â  Upon notice of Amwest Suretyâ€™s insolvency, SCDOT wrote to Southco requesting proof of a replacement payment bond within seven days.Â  Southco did not respond to this request.Â  Sloan properly performed its portion of the Project, but was not paid the $51,937.66 owed for the completed job.Â  Sloan did not file a claim against Amwest Surety through the companyâ€™s appointed receiver.
In January 2002, Sloan submitted written notice to SCDOT of its unpaid claim, recounting its hardships with the insolvent Amwest Surety.Â  Several months later, Southco submitted an affidavit to SCDOT averring all subcontractors on the Project were paid in full.Â  In accordance with the agencyâ€™s contract closeout procedures, which require an affidavit sworn by a principal of the general contractor stating all subcontractor claims are paid in full, SCDOT released the balance of the contract price to Southco.Â Â  
In December 2003, Sloan commenced the present action against Southco, SCDOT, and others for the unpaid contract price.Â  Sloan based its claim against SCDOT on South Carolina Code Sections 29-6-250 and 57-5-1660(a)(2) (Supp. 2004), asserting these statutes create an enforceable duty on the part of SCDOT to assure the payment bonds on its projects are, in fact, obtained and remain in effect until full payment.Â  SCDOT responded by filing a 12(b)(6), SCRCP, motion to dismiss.Â  The circuit court granted SCDOTâ€™s motion, concluding the statutes in question do not give rise to a private action against a violating state agency.Â  This appeal followed.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
â€œUnder Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, a defendant may move to dismiss based on a failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.â€Â  Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 201, 584 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 511 S.E.2d 69 (1999)).Â  The circuit court, in a civil action, may dismiss a claim when the defendant demonstrates the plaintiff has failed to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action in the pleadings filed with the court.Â  Id.Â  The motion cannot be granted if the facts set forth in the complaint and the inferences reasonably drawn therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the case.Â  Brown v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 366, 353 S.E.2d 697, 698 (1987). 
DISCUSSION
The circuit court concluded South Carolina Code Sections 29-6-250 and 57-5-1660(a)(2) (Supp. 2004) do not grant Sloan a private right of action against SCDOT.Â  We agree.
Section 57-5-1660 of the South Carolina Code reads in pertinent part:

(a) The Department of Transportation shall require that the contractor on every public highway construction contract, exceeding ten thousand dollars, furnish the Department of Transportation, county, or road district the following bonds, which shall become binding upon the award of the contract to such contractor:
  
(2) A payment bond with a surety or sureties satisfactory to Â  the awarding authority, and in the amount of not less than Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  fifty per cent of the contract, for the protection of all Â Â Â Â Â  persons supplying labor and materials in the prosecution Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  of work provided for in the contract for the use of each
such person.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-1660 (Supp. 2004).Â  This statute, enacted to protect subcontractors and materialmen on SCDOT projects, is often referred to as the â€œLittle Miller Act,â€ as it was modeled after the federal Miller Act, 40 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 270a & 270b (1986) (following 2002 amendment, these federal statutes are cited as 40 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 3131-3133).Â  Syro Steel Co. v. Eagle Constr. Co., 319 S.C. 180, 182, 460 S.E.2d 371, 373 (1995).Â  In addition, Section 29-6-250, enacted in 2000, requires payment bonds for the protection of subcontractors on certain government projects for the full amount of the contract. 
Section 29-6-250 reads in pertinent part as follows:

(1) When a government body is a party to a contract to improve real property, and the contract is for a sum in excess of fifty thousand dollars, the owner of the property shall require the contractor to provide a labor and material payment bond in the full amount of the contract.
. . . . 
(3) For the purposes of any contract covered by the provisions of this section, it is the duty of the entity contracting for the improvement to take reasonable steps to assure that the appropriate payment bond is issued and is in proper form.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-6-250 (Supp. 2004).
Our analysis of whether these statutes grant an individual or corporation the right to sue a violating state agency begins with the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-78-10 to -200 (2005).Â  â€œThe Tort Claims Act governs all tort claims against governmental entities.â€Â  Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358 S.C. 280, 292, 594 S.E.2d 557, 563 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Act, a limited waiver of the Stateâ€™s sovereign immunity from lawsuits, provides that State agencies are â€œliable for their torts in the same manner and to the same extent as a private individual under like circumstances,â€ subject to certain limitations and exemptions provided in the Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-40 (2005).Â  
When the Act is applied to the present facts, it is clear Sloan has no right to sue under the South Carolina Tort Claims Actâ€™s limited waiver of sovereign immunity.Â  Because the â€œLittle Miller Actâ€ and section 29-6-250 deal solely with government contracts, a private individual would never be in a position to require these statutorily mandated bonds, and thus could never be liable for the failure to require them.Â  See, e.g., Arvanis v. Noslo Engâ€™g Consultants, Inc., 739 F.2d 1287, 1290 (7th Cir. 1984); Hardaway Co. v. United States Army Corps of Engâ€™rs, 980 F.2d 1415, 1416-1417 & n.3 (11th Cir. 1993) (adopting this rationale regarding the federal Miller Act and Federal Tort Claims Act and acknowledging the application of similar analyses by the Fourth, Ninth, and Tenth Circuits).Â  Because a private individual could never be liable under the bonding statutes, the South Carolina Tort Claims Actâ€™s limited waiver of sovereign immunity does not apply to suits brought against the government under the statutes in question.Â  
We move now to the issue of whether South Carolinaâ€™s statutory bonding scheme, in itself, constitutes a waiver of SCDOTâ€™s sovereign immunity from suit.Â  Because the â€œLittle Miller Actâ€ is patterned after the federal Miller Act, cases construing the federal Miller Act, absent a contrary expression of legislative intent, will be given great weight in the interpretation of its South Carolina counterpart.Â  Syro Steel Co., 319 S.C. at 182, 460 S.E.2d at 373.Â  Federal cases construing the federal Miller Act are nearly unanimous in their interpretation.Â  Under federal law, failure of a government agency to follow the bonding requirements of the Miller Act, without other authority evincing a waiver of sovereign immunity, does not give rise to a private right of action against the agency.Â  See, e.g., Active Fire Sprinkler Corp. v. United States Postal Service, 811 F.2d 747, 752-753 (2nd Cir. 1987) (â€œThe Miller Act does not provide subcontractors with a right of recovery against the United States.â€); Arvanis, 739 F.2d at 1290 (â€œ[In the Miller Act] [t]here is clearly no waiver of sovereign immunity.â€); Devlin Lumber & Supply Corp. v. United States, 488 F.2d 88, 89 (4th Cir. 1973) (â€œ[A] violation of the Miller Act does not create liability on the part of the government . . . .); Acousti Engâ€™g Co. of Florida v. United States, 15 Cl. Ct. 698, 701 (Cl. Ct. 1988) (â€œThe Miller Act does not give subcontractors a substantive right to directly sue the United States for monies owed by [a] prime contractor.â€).
As there is no clear expression of legislative intent in South Carolina contrary to the interpretation of the federal Miller Act applied by the federal courts, we likewise conclude the statutes do not constitute a waiver of sovereign immunity and that a violation of our own statutory bonding scheme does not give rise to a private right of action against a state agency.[1]Â  In doing so, we share the concern of the circuit court judge that â€œsuch a result is at odds with the overall goal of Miller Act type legislation â€“ i.e., the protection of subcontractors who have no right to lien on government work.â€Â  Nevertheless, as stated by Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals:

â€œ[t]here does seem to be a gap in the statute; there is no provision for the contingency that both the contractor and the government contracting officer will ignore the bonding requirement.Â  However, this is not a gap that we can fill with a remedy . . . .â€

Arvanis, 739 F.2d at 1290.Â  Should the General Assembly desire South Carolinaâ€™s bonding scheme on state projects to allow private suits against the government, the statutes could easily call for such.Â  See, e.g., Kelly Energy Systems, Inc. v. Brd. of Commissioners of Clarke County, 396 S.E.2d 498, 499-500 (Ga. App. 1990) (â€œ[the Georgia bonding statute] provides that the governing body for which the work is done shall be liable to all materialmen for any loss resulting from the failure to require a payment bond.â€). 
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of SCDOTâ€™s motion to dismiss is
 AFFIRMED.  
 STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Because we decide this case on the grounds that South Carolinaâ€™s bonding scheme on state projects does not grant a subcontractor the right to bring a private action against a violating state agency, we need not address whether SCDOT complied with the statutes in question under the present facts.
