THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Curtis Earl, Claimant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        HTH Associates, Inc./Ace USA-Insurance Company of North America, Employer/Carrier,
        And Advance Auto Parts/Royal Insurance Company of America, Statutory Employer/Carrier,
        And The SC Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund, Defendants,
        Of whom Ace USA-Insurance Company of North America is the Appellant.
        And Curtis Earl, Advance Auto Parts, Royal Insurance Company of America, and HTH Associates, Inc. are the Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4086
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed February 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Walter Hilton Barefoot, of Florence, for Appellant.
        John S. Nichols, of Columbia, Kenneth W. Harrell, of North Charleston, and Stephen L. Brown and Wallace G. Holland, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Ace USA Insurance Company of North America (INA) appeals the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s order, affirmed by the circuit court, finding insurance coverage for HTH Associates, Inc. under an INA policy.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
 In 1992, HTH purchased a one-year workersâ€™ compensation insurance policy from INA.Â  On April 5, 1992, pursuant to regulatory requirements, INA electronically submitted the policy C35274522 to the National Council on Compensation Insurance (NCCI).Â  INA then mailed a hard copy of the policy to NCCI.Â  The hard copy identified the policy as number WOCC35274522.Â  The only difference between the two filings was the prefix â€œWOCâ€ in the policy number of the hard copy.Â  NCCIâ€™s computer system registered HTH as having two separate active policies.Â  
In 1993, HTH learned it was not required to provide workersâ€™ compensation coverage and decided not to renew the INA policy.Â  However, because HTH had initially elected coverage, Regulation 67-404 required HTH to file a Form 38 Notice of Withdrawal.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-404 (1990).Â  The failure to submit a Form 38 results in a company still operating under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act and subjects the company to possible sanctions.Â  Id.Â  HTH never filed a Form 38.Â  
When HTH failed to renew the INA policy, INA, pursuant to Regulation 67-406, filed a notice of termination directly with the NCCI.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-406 (Supp. 2005).Â  INA correctly canceled policy number C35274522, and the termination became effective May 11, 1993.Â  INA believed it had canceled HTHâ€™s sole policy.Â  However, according to the NCCI computer system, the WOCC35274522 policy was still in effect. Â 
In 2000, Curtis Earl, an employee of HTH, was in a work-related automobile accident.[1] Â At the time, HTH was engaged in the business of setting up new stores for Advance Auto Parts all over the southeastern United States.Â  Gary Smith, the Director of Coverage and Compliance at the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, investigated coverage.Â  On the initial hearing notice, Smith indicated HTH had no coverage.Â  Upon further investigation, Smith concluded HTH had coverage under the policy identified in the records of the NCCI as WOCC35274522.Â  
Earl filed this action against HTH, Advance and its insurer, Royal Insurance Company of America, and the South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund.Â  Earl alleged HTH was his employer and was subject to the Act, the INA policy provided HTH with coverage, and the Royal Insurance policy also provided coverage based on Earlâ€™s statutory employment with Advance. 
The single commissioner found, inter alia, HTH was subject to the Act and Earl was HTHâ€™s employee.Â  The commissioner also found INA failed to properly cancel policy WOCC35274522, and therefore, the policy was still in effect.Â  The commissioner found INA liable for all payments related to Earlâ€™s injuries.Â  The full commission affirmed, adopting the commissionerâ€™s findings in full.Â  However, the commission made the additional finding that Advance was Earlâ€™s statutory employer and Royal Insurance would cover Earlâ€™s injuries if, on appeal, the court found no coverage under any INA policy.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  INA appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing which of two carriers provided insurance in a workerâ€™s compensation action, our supreme court applied the following standard of review:

  Review of a decision of the workersâ€™ compensation commission is governed by the Administrative Procedures Act.Â  Although this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the full commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, it may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law. 

Rodriguez v. Romero, 363 S.C. 80, 84, 610 S.E.2d 488, 490 (2005) (internal citations omitted).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
 INA contends it properly canceled HTHâ€™s sole policy and thus INA provided no coverage at the time of Earlâ€™s accident.Â  We disagree.Â  Pursuant to Regulation 67-406(A), the NCCI is the commissionâ€™s â€œauthorized agentâ€ for filing a report of coverage and notice of termination.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-406(A) (Supp. 2005). Â Notice of termination of a policy must be filed as specified in the regulations.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-406(E) (Supp. 2005).Â  Regulation 67-406 provides:

  B.Â  The insurance carrier shall file a report of coverage and notice of termination directly with the NCCI.Â  The date of receipt by the NCCI is deemed the date of filing with the Commission.
  F.Â  To cancel workersâ€™ compensation insurance coverage, not to renew workersâ€™ compensation insurance coverage, or to reinstate a workersâ€™ compensation insurance policy, the insurance carrier shall file with the NCCI an NCCI Form WC 89 06 09 A.
  
          (1)Â  The insurance carrier may file this notice with the NCCI thirty or more days before the effective date.
     (2)Â  Insurance expiration, termination or cancellation shall not be effective until after thirty days from the date of receipt by NCCI of the NCCI Form WC 89 06 09 A.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-406 (Supp. 2005).Â  An insurance policy is deemed continuous until a notice of cancellation is filed.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-406 (E) (Supp. 2005).Â  
Several rules of statutory construction compel us to affirm the circuit court.Â  First, workersâ€™ compensation statutes and regulations are to be construed liberally in favor of coverage.Â  See Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 22, 416 S.E.2d 639, 641 (1992).Â  Second, because workersâ€™ compensation is a creature of statute, â€œwe are bound to strictly construe the terms of the statute . . . .â€Â  Brown v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 354 S.C. 436, 441, 581 S.E.2d 836, 838 (2003).Â  Finally, the decision of an administrative agency interpreting its own regulations is given great deference.Â  Goodman v. City of Columbia, 318 S.C. 488, 491, 458 S.E.2d 531, 532 (1995).Â  Under a strict interpretation of the regulations, construing them in favor of coverage, and reviewing the commissionâ€™s own interpretation of the regulations, we find INA failed to notify the NCCI of the cancellation of the policy identified by INA as WOCC35274522.Â  Gary Smith, the Director of the Coverage and Compliance Department of the commission, testified that if policy WOCC35274522 had been canceled in the NCCI records, his department would have initiated a non-compliance investigation due to HTHâ€™s failure to file a Form 38.Â  Smith admitted this case presented an anomaly, and it was his personal opinion the two policy numbers referred to the same policy.Â  Smith further acknowledged INA would not have known that two different policies had been set up unless it requested a listing of all its open policies.Â  Smith concluded, however, that there is no regulatory provision requiring an employer actually pay premiums and no provision protecting a carrier in the event of a clerical error.Â  Smith ultimately concluded on behalf of the commission that the WOC policy was not canceled pursuant to the regulations.Â  
We find other support for our decision.Â  For instance, in Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law, the authors conclude the requirements for canceling a workersâ€™ compensation insurance policy are exacting and strictly construed because of the â€œessential role of insurance in the compensation process, and the serious potential effects of noninsurance on both employer and employee . . . .â€Â  9 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 150.03 (2005).Â  An insurerâ€™s failure to strictly comply with the regulations renders a termination ineffective.Â  Id.Â  
Likewise, the District of Columbia Court of Appeals addressed a nearly identical issue under the Longshoremen and Harbor Workerâ€™s Act in Scott v. Hoage, 73 F.2d 114 (D.C. App. 1934), and found coverage.Â  In Scott, the insurance carrier misstated the policy number in its notice of cancellation.Â  Scott, 73 F.2d at 115.Â  The recipient clerk filed the cancellation notice, assuming a same-numbered policy was forthcoming.Â  A policy with the erroneous number never arrived, and the original policy was never canceled.Â  Finding the policy still in effect the court stated:

  It is probable that the mistake in numbers was the result of clerical error only.Â  Nevertheless we think that misdescription of the policy number in the notice vitiates it.Â  The duty rests upon the company to send a correct notice, and inasmuch as it failed to do so in this case, it did not accomplish the purpose for which it was sent.

Id. at 117.Â  We likewise find INAâ€™s notice failed to cancel policy WOCC35274522.Â  
Finally, we find the most equitable result in this case is to charge the party responsible for the mistake, INA.Â  INAâ€™s hard copy notification designating coverage under policy WOCC35274522, after its electronic notification of policy number C35274522, caused the error.Â  Smith testified the commission uses the NCCI computer system as authority for determining whether a policy exists or whether it has been canceled.Â  If the NCCI computer had not shown coverage under policy WOCC35274522, the commission would have filed noncompliance proceedings against HTH for failure to file a Form 38.Â  However, because the NCCI computer listed HTH as covered under the WOCC35274522 policy, no proceedings were initiated.Â  In short, INA created the problem by submitting the same policy twice, identified by two different numbers.[2]Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â In 2002, Earl died as a result of injuries sustained in the accident.
[2] Â Although insurers do not usually request all their open policies from the NCCI, Smith testified that had INA made the request it would have known the policy for HTH was still in effect.Â

        Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.

Elliott, Â Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Michael Brian Flynn appeals following convictions for burglary in the first degree, two counts of armed robbery, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Specifically, Flynn argues the trial court erred in failing to find that the State violated Batson v. Kentucky[1] by using five peremptory strikes to remove black females from his jury.
FACTS
After the jury was qualified, Flynnâ€™s counsel raised a Batson challenge based on the fact that the State used all its strikes to remove black females from the jury.[2]Â  The trial court then advised the State that it had the burden of presenting a racially neutral explanation for the strikes.Â  The following explanations were presented:

  Your Honor, as it relates to [Juror] 124, she had a violation of [a] check law.Â  In addition, she was young . . . The next person, [Juror 76], was a person who works at Food Lion as a customer service representative . . . In her employment, she deals with complaints day in and day out, about bickering and things of that nature, and I thought that because there would be some of that in this case that I wouldnâ€™t want somebody in that kind of job who is dealing always with conflicts and hassles in her job . . . [Juror] 21 . . . is a Head Start director.Â  I view that as a very liberal job and thatâ€™s the reason why I struck her . . . [Juror 91] works at Baptist Hill High School, . . . as a secretary, and I thought she might have sympathy for young people . . . [Juror 154] also has a fraud check.Â  Sheâ€™s young, and she had - - she was a cook or worked in the cafeteria at the College of Charleston.Â  Between all three of those things, I moved to strike her.Â  (emphasis added).

Defense counsel took exception to the Stateâ€™s reasons for striking Juror 21, the Head Start Director.Â  Counsel argued that being liberal is not an appropriate reason for being stricken from a jury.Â  The State then expounded on its reasons for striking her:Â  â€œYour Honor, I believe that is a social welfare kind of program, and as director she is liberal in nature. Â Itâ€™s a liberal type of attitude and job, and that is why I struck her.â€Â  
The trial court ruled that given the nature of the case and progress of the trial to that point, it would be possible to consider a Head Start director as an improper juror.Â  The court then stated: â€œIâ€™m going to conclude that itâ€™s race neutral, particularly in view of the fact that the Defendant is a young white Caucasian.Â  That particular juror is female, African-American.Â  I conclude thatâ€™s race neutral.â€Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
On appeal, Flynn argues that the trial court erred in not finding the State violated Batson in regard to its treatment of Juror 21.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œThe Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire person on the basis of race or gender.â€Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001).Â  The purposes of Batson are to â€œâ€˜protect the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial by a jury of the defendantâ€™s peers, protect each venire personâ€™s right not to be excluded from jury service for discriminatory reasons, and preserve confidence in the fairness of our system of justice by seeking to eradicate discrimination in the jury selection process.â€™â€Â  State v. Rayfield, 357 S.C. 497, 501, 593 S.E.2d 486, 488 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 628-29, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1999)).
Our supreme court established the procedure for a Batson hearing in State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 123-24, 470 S.E.2d 366, 371-72 (1996).Â  Once a party requests a hearing, the burden shifts to the proponent of the strike who must present a racially neutral reason or explanation.Â  Id.Â  At this point, the burden shifts back to the party challenging the strike to show the explanation is merely pretextual.Â  Id.Â  This is generally accomplished by showing that similarly situated people of another race were placed on the jury.Â  Id.Â  It is important to note that the â€œproponent of the peremptory challenges will not have any burden of presenting reasonably specific, legitimate explanations for the strikes.Â  Instead, [he or she] need only present racially neutral explanations.â€Â  Id.
In the current case, Flynn argues the State â€œadvanced a racial stereotypeâ€ to justify striking Juror 21.Â  We disagree.Â  As noted previously, the State asserted that due to her employment, it believed Juror 21 was â€œliberal.â€Â  As Flynn has offered no evidence other than a conclusory assertion of racial motivation, we find the trial court did not err in failing to find a Batson violation.
AFFIRMED. [3]
STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] 476 U.S. 79, 106 S. Ct. 1712 (1986).
[2] Flynn was 18 at the time of trial and is a white male.Â  
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The South Carolina Municipal Insurance and Risk Fund, Appellant,
        v.
        The City of Myrtle Beach and James E. Daniels, individually and as class representative, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4088
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed February 27, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      J.R. Murphy, Adam J. Neil, and Tony Catone, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
      Charles Bernhart Jordan, of Myrtle Beach; Gene McCain Connell, Jr., of Surfside Beach; for Respondents.
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  In this declaratory judgment action, the South Carolina Municipal Insurance and Risk Fund (SCMIRF) appeals a summary judgment order requiring it to indemnify the City of Myrtle Beach (the City) for refunds of monies collected pursuant to a city ordinance that had been declared unconstitutional.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In February 1996, James Daniels filed a class action lawsuit against the City, challenging Myrtle Beach City Code section 21-7(g) and the Cityâ€™s implementation of that section.Â  The ordinance stated the following: 

  Any outstanding charges associated with rental or leased properties or accounts which are not covered by the tenantâ€™s deposit shall be the responsibility of the property owner.Â  

The effect of the ordinance was that landlords became secondarily liable for their tenantsâ€™ water bills.Â  In implementing the ordinance, the City would refuse to provide water service to leased property with outstanding water bills.Â  As a result of this refusal, landlords and new tenants could be required to pay water charges incurred by prior tenants. 
On December 28, 2001, the master-in-equity for Horry County granted judgment to the class, holding the ordinance and implementing policies violated federal statutory law and the constitutional guarantees of substantive due process, procedural due process, equal protection, and just compensation.Â  The master further ordered that each member of the class was entitled to a refund of any monies paid for anotherâ€™s water bill.Â  
During the time of some of the allegations in the class action complaint, the City was insured under a general liability insurance policy issued by SCMIRF.Â  The pertinent section of the policy read as follows:

  SCMIRF agrees, subject to limitations, terms, and conditions stated in the General Provisions, Section I and Hereunder mentioned: 
  1.     To indemnify the Member and Covered Person(s) for all sums which the Member or Covered Person(s) shall be obligated to pay by reason of the liability imposed upon the covered Person(s) by law for damages on account of . . . damage to or destruction of property or the loss of use thereof arising out of any Occurrence.Â  

The policy also listed certain actions as exclusions to coverage, noting in particular that â€œthis coverage under this section does not apply: . . . to inverse condemnation, condemnation, temporary taking, permanent taking, or any claim arising out of or in any way connected with the operation of the principles of eminent domain, adverse possession or dedication by adverse use.â€Â  
On February 25, 2003, SCMIRF filed the present action in the Horry County Court of Common Pleas requesting declarations that this policy did not cover any of the claims or damages asserted by the class against the City and that SCMIRF was not required to provide a defense to the City in the underlying class action.Â  The City answered with a general denial and various affirmative defenses on March 13, 2003.Â  On September 4, 2003, SCMIRF filed a motion for summary judgment.Â  A hearing on the motion took place November 1, 2004.Â  With the request and consent of the parties, the trial court converted the motion into cross-motions for summary judgment.Â  On December 10, 2004, the trial court filed an order denying summary judgment to SCMIRF and granting summary judgment to the City.Â  
The trial court concluded the refunds constituted â€œdamagesâ€ under the insuring policy.Â  The trial court also concluded the wrongful collection of money was â€œproperty damageâ€ and the Cityâ€™s action pursuant to its ordinance was an unintended â€œoccurrence.â€Â  Finally, the trial court concluded the inverse condemnation exclusion did not preclude coverage.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
We address only SCMIRFâ€™s contention that the policy expressly excluded coverage for claims based on a taking.Â  We hold this argument is a sufficient basis on which to reverse the appealed order.
Regarding insurance policies, the supreme court has noted that â€œrules of construction requires clauses of exclusion to be narrowly interpreted and clauses of inclusion to be broadly construed.â€[1]Â  â€œThis rule of construction inures to the benefit of the insured.â€[2]Â  Nevertheless, â€œ[w]hen the contract language is clear and unambiguous, the language alone determines the contractâ€™s force, and terms must be construed to give effect to their â€˜plain, ordinary, and popular meaning.â€™â€[3]Â  â€œCourts may not torture the ordinary meaning of language to extend coverage expressly excluded by the terms of a policy.â€[4]Â  
Citing this courtâ€™s decision in Isle of Palms Pest Control v. Monticello Insurance Co.,[5] the trial court held that, because inverse condemnation was only one of several grounds upon which the master assessed liability against the City and because the exclusion did not apply to the other grounds for the masterâ€™s ruling, namely due process and equal protection, the inverse condemnation exclusion did not operate to preclude coverage.Â  We disagree with these holdings.
First, the portion of Isle of Palms on which the trial court relied in reaching this conclusion concerned only a duty to defend, not a duty to pay.[6]Â  In contrast, the focus of this appeal is not on SCMIRFâ€™s duty to defend but rather on whether the policy it issued to the City required it to cover damages and attorney fees assessed against the City in the underlying suit.Â  Although an insurer may have an initial obligation to provide a defense to a claim because â€œthe underlying complaint creates a possibility of coverage under an insurance policy,â€[7] this obligation is distinct from the insurerâ€™s responsibility to cover the claim.[8]
Second, we disagree with the conclusion in the appealed order that, because the master also cited the grounds of due process and equal protection to support his finding that Myrtle Beach City Code section 21-7(g) was invalid, the inverse condemnation exclusion did not operate to preclude coverage.Â  
As stated earlier, the policy expressly provided that liability coverage would not apply â€œto inverse condemnation, condemnation, temporary taking, permanent taking, or any claim arising out of or in any way connected with the operation of the principles of eminent domain, adverse possession or dedication by adverse use.â€Â  In granting judgment to the plaintiffs in the class action and ordering the City to make refunds to the class members, the master concluded that requiring one person to pay anotherâ€™s water bill to obtain service amounted to a â€œtaking of property which violates the United States and the South Carolina Constitutions.â€Â  Although, as the trial court correctly observed, the master also cited due process and equal protection as reasons to require the City to pay refunds to the plaintiffs in the class action, the heart of the controversy in that lawsuit was the taking by the City of the class membersâ€™ money without just compensation.Â  As SCMIRF argued in its brief, the violation of the class membersâ€™ rights to due process and equal protection would not have occurred but for the wrongful exercise by the City of its eminent domain power.[9]Â  Because the claim at issue in this appeal fell within a policy exclusion, SCMIRF should not be required to indemnify the City for its loss.[10] 
REVERSED.
ANDERSON and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  McPherson v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 310 S.C. 316, 319, 426 S.E.2d 770-71 (1993).
[2]Â  Id.
[3]Â  Dorman v. Allstate Ins. Co., 332 S.C. 176, 178, 504 S.E.2d 127, 129 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting Gray v. State Farm Auto Ins. Co., 327 S.C. 646, 650, 491 S.E.2d 272, 274 (Ct. App. 1997)).
[4]Â  Falkosky v. Allstate Ins. Co., 311 S.C. 369, 371, 429 S.E.2d 194, 196 (Ct. App.), affâ€™d as modified, 312 S.C. 210, 439 S.E.2d 836 (1993).
[5]Â  319 S.C. 12, 459 S.E.2d 318 (Ct. App. 1994), affâ€™d, 321 S.C. 310, 468 S.E.2d 304 (1996).
[6]Â  The section cited by the trial court reads as follows:Â  â€œWhile the [third-party] complaint also includes allegations of intentional conduct which would not be covered by the policy, the inclusion of some non-covered claims does not abrogate an insurerâ€™s duty to defend when a complaint raises claims covered by the policy.â€Â  Id. at 15, 459 S.E.2d at 319 (emphasis added). 
[7]Â  Id.
[8]Â  See Sloan Constr. Co. v. Central Natâ€™l Ins. Co. of Omaha, 269 S.C. 183, 186, 236 S.E.2d 818, 820 (1977) (stating that, although the duty to defend and the obligation to pay a judgment against an insured â€œare related in the sense that the duty to defend depends on an initial or apparent potential liability to satisfy the judgment, the duty to defend exists regardless of the insurerâ€™s ultimate liability to the insuredâ€); cf. Iowa Kemper Ins. Co. v. Stone, 269 N.W.2d 885, 887-88 (Minn. 1978) (â€œ[A]lthough the liability insurer generally must undertake the defense of its insured based upon the allegations in the third-party complaint, the allegations of negligence in [the third-party] complaint can impose no continuing obligation where coverage has been declared excluded in separate judicial proceedings.â€).
[9]Â  See Reagan v. Farmersâ€™ Loan & Trust Co., 154 U.S. 362, 399 (1894) (â€œThe equal protection of the laws, which, by the fourteenth amendment, no state can deny to the individual, forbids legislation, in whatever form it may be enacted, by which the property of one individual is, without compensation, wrested from him for the benefit of another, or of the public.â€); cf. T.E. Wannamaker, Inc. v. City of Orangeburg, 278 S.C. 637, 639, 300 S.E.2d 729, 730 (1983) (recognizing equal protection and due process as â€œconstitutional requirementsâ€ in a condemnation proceeding). 
[10] Cf. McPherson, 310 S.C. at 320, 426 S.E.2d at 772 (upholding this courtâ€™s determination that the policy at issue excluded coverage for the plaintiffâ€™s injuries â€œregardless of the legal theory by which they are claimedâ€) (affâ€™g as modified 306 S.C. 456, 412 S.E.2d 445 (Ct. App. 1993)); B.L.G. Enters. v. First Fin. Ins. Co., 328 S.C. 374, 377, 491 S.E.2d 695, 697 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œ[I]nsurers have no duty to defend the insured where damages are caused by a reason clearly excluded under the policy.â€), affâ€™d, 334 S.C. 529, 514 S.E.2d 327 (1999).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Suchart Taylor, Respondent,
        v.
        South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4089
Formerly Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-051
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 20, 2006Â  
Refiled February 27, 2006 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Frank L. Valenta, Jr., and Kelli Gregg Maddox, of Blythewood, for Appellant.
        Michael Sean Oâ€™Neal, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles (the Department) appeals the trial courtâ€™s order reversing the administrative hearing officerâ€™s order sustaining the suspension of Suchart Taylorâ€™s driverâ€™s license.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
On September 1, 2004, Officer Hamm of the South Carolina Highway Patrol responded to a report of a vehicle accident on Interstate 26 in Berkley County.Â  When Officer Hamm arrived at the scene of the accident, paramedics were treating Taylor for his injuries.Â  During a break in the treatment, Officer Hamm approached Taylorâ€™s vehicle.Â  As he approached, he smelled an odor of beer emanating from the area around Taylor.Â  Officer Hamm arrested Taylor for driving under the influence of alcohol (DUI).Â  Due to the extent of Taylorâ€™s injuries, Taylor was transported to the hospital.Â  
At the hospital, Officer Hamm determined Taylor could not take a breath test due to the heavy mouth injuries he sustained from the accident.Â  Officer Hamm requested a blood sample from Taylor.Â  Taylor refused to provide a blood sample, and refused to sign the implied consent form.Â  Because Taylor refused to sign the form, Officer Hamm read it out loud, but did not provide Taylor a tangible copy.Â  Thus, Taylor heard his implied consent rights but neither read nor signed the implied consent form.Â  
Because Taylor refused chemical testing, Officer Hamm issued him a notice of suspension of his driverâ€™s license.Â  Shortly thereafter, Taylor requested a hearing to challenge the suspension of his license.Â  On October 13, 2004, the hearing officer sustained the suspension of Taylorâ€™s license.Â  Taylor then petitioned the trial court to review the administrative hearing officerâ€™s order.Â  The trial court heard Taylorâ€™s petition and reversed the hearing officerâ€™s order.Â  The Department now appeals the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for an appeal from an order of an administrative agency.Â  Section 1-23-380(A)(6) of the South Carolina Code (2005) provides: 

  The court shall not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  The court may affirm the decision of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings.Â  The court may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are: 
  (a) in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions. . . .

â€œThe findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Motor Vehicles v. Nelson, 364 S.C. 514, 519, 613 S.E.2d 544, 547 (2005).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œIn reviewing a final decision of an administrative agency, the circuit court essentially sits as an appellate court to review alleged errors committed by the agency.â€Â  Id.Â  
DISCUSSION
The Department argues the trial court erred in reversing the order of the administrative hearing officer.Â  We agree.
In South Carolina, operating a motor vehicle is a privilege of the State, not a right of the individual.Â Â  

  The license to operate a motor vehicle upon the public highways of this state is not a property right, but is a mere privilege subject to reasonable regulations under the police power in the interest of the public safety and welfare. Â Such privilege is always subject to revocation or suspension for any cause relating to public safety. Â However, the privilege cannot be revoked arbitrarily or capriciously.Â  

Sponar v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 361 S.C. 35, 39, 603 S.E.2d 412, 415 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  As part of this privilege, individuals operating motor vehicles implicitly consent to chemical tests of their breath, blood, or urine to determine whether they are driving while under the influence of drugs or alcohol.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950 (Supp. 2004).Â  
The implied consent laws of this State attempt to balance the interest of the State in maintaining safe highways with the interest of the individual in maintaining personal autonomy free from arbitrary or overbearing State action.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court articulated this policy in S.C. Depâ€™t of Motor Vehicles v. Nelson, 364 S.C. 514, 521, 613 S.E.2d 544, 548 (2005), when the court stated: 

  The implied consent laws are driven by public policy considerations. Â The State has a strong interest in maintaining safe highways and roads. Â One way to accomplish this goal is to enact laws directed at minimizing drunk driving. Â 

Section 56-5-2950 of the South Carolina Code provides:

  No tests may be administered or samples obtained unless the person has been informed in writing that:
  (1) he does not have to take the test or give the samples, but that his privilege to drive must be suspended or denied for at least ninety days if he refuses to submit to the tests and that his refusal may be used against him in court; 
  (2)Â  his privilege to drive must be suspended for at least thirty days if he takes the tests or gives the samples and has an alcohol concentration of fifteen one-hundredths of one percent or more; 
  (3)Â  he has the right to have a qualified person of his own choosing conduct addition independent tests at his expense; 
  (4) he has the right to request an administrative hearing within thirty days of the issuance of the notice of suspension; and 
  (5)Â  if he does not request an administrative hearing or if his suspension is upheld at the administrative hearing, he must enroll in an Alcohol and Drug Safety Action Program. 

The aforementioned administrative hearing must be held within thirty days after request for the hearing is received.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2951(F) (Supp. 2004).Â  By statute, the â€œscope of the hearing must be limited to whether the person: (1) was lawfully arrested or detained; (2) was advised in writing of the rights enumerated in Section 56-5-2950; [or] (3) refused to submit to a test pursuant to Section 56-5-2950 . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2951(F).Â Â  
The Department argues the trial court erred in reversing the administrative hearing officerâ€™s order because Taylor did not demonstrate how he was prejudiced by the fact that he did not receive a copy of the implied consent form from Officer Hamm.Â  We agree. 
In State v. Huntley, 349 S.C. 1, 6, 562 S.E.2d 472, 474 (2002), the South Carolina Supreme Court reversed the trial court and held that the results of a breathalyzer test should not have been suppressed for a violation of section 56-5-2950 because the defendant was not prejudiced by the violation.Â  The trial court suppressed the breathalyzer test results because the breathalyzer operator tested the breathalyzer machine with a simulator test solution containing an alcohol level of .10 percent rather than the .08 percent mandated by statute.Â  The supreme court reasoned that because the test merely determined the reliability of the breathalyzer machineâ€™s results it was â€œirrelevant whether the simulator test [was operated] using an alcohol level of .10 or .08 percent.â€Â  Id.Â  The supreme court concluded, â€œEven if the breathalyzer operator did not use the simulator test solution at the alcohol concentration required by [section 56-5-2950], [the defendant] was not prejudiced.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, the supreme court reversed the suppression of the breathalyzer test results because the defendant was not prejudiced by the statutory violation committed by the breathalyzer operator.Â  Consequently, the Huntley decision dictates that a violation of section 56-5-2950 without resulting prejudice will not lead to a suppression of the evidence obtained pursuant to this section.Â  
Taylor argues he was not informed of the implied consent rights in writing as provided by section 56-5-2950.Â  Taylor does not argue that he did not receive the implied consent rights, or that he would have provided a blood test if he had received the implied consent rights in writing.Â  Therefore, Taylor was not prejudiced by the fact that Officer Hamm read the implied consent rights out loud.Â  Because Taylor was not prejudiced, the trial court erred in reversing the administrative hearing officerâ€™s order.Â Â Â Â  
Accordingly, the order of the trial court is 
REVERSED.
KITTREDGE, WILLIAMS, JJ., AND CURETON, A.J., CONCUR.
